opinions.snippet:
OPINION
 

  BATCHELDER, Circuit Judge.
 

  Respondent Betty Mitchell (“the Warden”) appeals the district court’s grant of a writ of habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2254 to Ohio death row inmate Jay D. Scott. The district court granted the writ on the basis of only one of the grounds raised in his petition, finding all of the other grounds either defaulted or mer

caseNameFull: STATE of Idaho, Plaintiff-Respondent, v. Erick Virgil HALL, Defendant-Appellant. Erick Virgil Hall, Petitioner-Appellant, v. State of Idaho, Respondent.

opinions.snippet:
BRODY, Justice
Erick Virgil Hall was convicted of first-degree murder, first-degree kidnapping, and rape. He was sentenced to death for murder and to consecutive, fixed life terms for first-degree kidnapping and rape. Hall petitioned for post-conviction relief, alleging numerous errors at trial. Hall's petition for post-conviction relief was summarily dismissed. Hall's direct and post-conviction appeals are consolidated pursuant to

caseNameFull: Anderson v. Reith-Riley Construction Company, Incorporated.

opinions.snippet:
The single question here presented is the correctness of the ruling of the trial court in sustaining a demurrer to appellant's complaint.
The complaint alleges that on August 26, 1939, appellee owned a lot in Homewood addition in Portage Township, St. Joseph county, which was located at one corner of the intersection of Mayflower road and Ardmore trail. That Mayflower road is constructed over and across Ardmore trail so as to form an overpass, and for a distance of several hundred feet

posture:
From the St. Joseph Superior Court;  J. Fred Bingham , Judge.

Action by Carl C. Anderson against Reith-Riley Construction Company, Incorporated, for damages for the death of plaintiff's son which occurred in a sand pit on defendant's premises. From a judgment for defendant, entered after its demurrer to plaintiff's complaint was sustained, plaintiff appealed.

 Affirmed.  By the court in banc.

opinions.snippet: On Motion for Rehearing Appellant’s forceful motion for rehearing impels us to discuss at length the question which has been characterized as one of the most troublesome in the modern law of evidence: the evidential effect of appellee’s testimony that he did not agree to “assure or guarantee” anything, and whether it is so binding on him as to be conclusive against him on the second issue.1

caseName: Dozier v. Haziel v. United States
caseNameFull: Dozier v. HAZIEL, Appellant, v. UNITED STATES of America, Appellee
court: Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit

opinions.snippet:
BAZELON, Chief Judge.
 

  Dozier Haziel was 16 years old when he was arrested for armed robbery and assault with a dangerous weapon in September 1965. The Juvenile Court waived jurisdiction to the District Court, where he was ultimately tried as an adult and convicted. Today he is 19 years old. He advances two contentions in this appeal
